questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the International Plumbing Code?

explanation.short: IPC purpose is to protect public health and safety.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 101.2, the purpose of the code is to establish minimum requirements to safeguard public health, safety, and welfare through proper plumbing design and installation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 101.2 for code purpose.

questions.question: Who has authority to enforce the plumbing code?

explanation.short: Code official/building department enforces the code.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 103.1, the code official (typically the building department) is charged with administration and enforcement of the plumbing code.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 103.1 for enforcement authority.

questions.question: When is a plumbing permit required?

choices.text: Before installation, alteration, or repair of plumbing

explanation.short: Permit required before any plumbing work begins.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 105.1, a permit is required for the installation, alteration, or repair of any plumbing system. Work shall not begin until permit is obtained.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 105.1 for permit requirements.

questions.question: What minor repairs typically do NOT require a permit?

choices.text: Replacing faucet washers or clearing stoppages

explanation.short: Minor repairs like washers and clearing stoppages exempt.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 105.2, minor repairs such as replacing faucet parts, clearing stoppages, and repairing leaks (not involving concealed piping) are typically exempt from permits.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 105.2 for permit exemptions.

questions.question: When must plumbing work be inspected?

explanation.short: Inspection required before concealment and at completion.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.1, plumbing work shall be inspected before concealing and upon completion. Rough-in inspection occurs before walls are closed.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.1 for inspection requirements.

questions.question: What test is required for DWV piping before final approval?

explanation.short: DWV requires water or air pressure test.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.2, DWV systems shall be tested with water to full rough-in height or with air at 5 psi for 15 minutes minimum.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.2 for DWV testing.

questions.question: What is the minimum air test pressure for DWV systems?

explanation.short: DWV air test pressure is 5 psi minimum.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.2, when testing DWV with air, the system shall maintain a pressure of at least 5 psi for a minimum of 15 minutes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.2 for air test pressure.

questions.question: What is the minimum water test requirement for DWV?

choices.text: Fill to highest opening for 15 minutes

explanation.short: Water test: 10 feet head minimum for 15 minutes.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.2, water test shall fill system to highest opening with 10-foot minimum head for at least 15 minutes. Multi-story may be tested in sections.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.2 for water test requirements.

questions.question: What is the final test for drainage systems?

explanation.short: Final test is visual inspection with running water.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.3, the final test consists of visual inspection with water flow through fixtures to verify proper drainage and no leaks at joints.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.3 for final test requirements.

questions.question: What test is required for water supply piping?

explanation.short: Water supply tested at working pressure or 40 psi minimum.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.5, water distribution piping shall be tested at the greater of normal working pressure or 40 psi for the duration required.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.5 for water piping test.

questions.question: What quality of materials must be used in plumbing systems?

explanation.short: Only listed, labeled, and approved materials allowed.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 301.2, materials used in plumbing systems shall be listed, labeled, and in accordance with approved standards. Quality is assured through third-party testing.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 301.2 for material requirements.

questions.question: What does 'listed' mean for plumbing materials?

choices.text: Included in a testing agency's list of approved products

explanation.short: Listed means included in an approved testing agency's list.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2 definitions, 'listed' means equipment or materials that appear in a list published by an approved testing agency (like UL, NSF, IAPMO) indicating compliance with standards.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for listed definition.

questions.question: What does 'labeled' mean for plumbing materials?

choices.text: Bears mark of approved testing agency

explanation.short: Labeled means bearing mark of approved testing agency.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2 definitions, 'labeled' means equipment or materials bearing the label, symbol, or mark of an approved testing agency indicating compliance with applicable standards.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for labeled definition.

questions.question: Can alternative materials or methods be approved?

choices.text: Yes, if approved by code official

explanation.short: Code official may approve alternatives that meet intent.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 104.11, the code official may approve alternative materials, designs, or methods that demonstrate equivalence to code requirements in quality, strength, and safety.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 104.11 for alternative approval.

questions.question: What is required when pipes pass through fire-rated assemblies?

explanation.short: Firestopping required to maintain fire rating.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 305.5, penetrations through fire-resistance-rated assemblies shall be protected with approved firestop systems to maintain the required fire rating.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 305.5 for firestopping.

questions.question: What protection is required for pipes in exterior walls?

explanation.short: Pipes in exterior walls must be protected from freezing.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 305.6, water piping installed in exterior walls, attics, or other locations subject to freezing shall be adequately protected by insulation or other means.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 305.6 for freeze protection.

questions.question: What is required when piping is installed in corrosive soil?

explanation.short: Corrosive soil requires resistant material or protection.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 305.2, piping installed in corrosive soils shall be of approved corrosion-resistant material or shall be protected by an approved protective covering.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 305.2 for corrosion protection.

questions.question: What is a plumbing fixture?

choices.text: Device for receiving water discharge and conveying to drainage

explanation.short: Fixture receives discharge and conveys to drainage system.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2 definitions, a plumbing fixture is a device that receives water and/or waste matter and discharges into the drainage system (sink, toilet, lavatory, etc.).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for fixture definition.

questions.question: What is potable water?

choices.text: Water safe for drinking and cooking

explanation.short: Potable water is safe for drinking and cooking.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2 definitions, potable water is water that is free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful effects, suitable for drinking and cooking.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for potable water definition.

questions.question: Who is responsible for code compliance of plumbing work?

explanation.short: Owner and contractor are responsible for compliance.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 105.4, the permit holder (owner or contractor) is responsible for compliance with the code. The inspector verifies but does not assume responsibility for compliance.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 105.4 for responsibility.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a trap in the drainage system?

choices.text: Prevent sewer gases from entering building

explanation.short: Traps prevent sewer gases from entering building.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1001.1, traps maintain a water seal that prevents sewer gases, odors, and vermin from passing from the drainage system into the building.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1001.1 for trap purpose.

questions.question: What is the purpose of venting in the drainage system?

choices.text: Maintain trap seals and equalize pressure

explanation.short: Vents maintain trap seals and equalize system pressure.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 901.2, vent systems allow air circulation, protect trap seals from siphonage and back pressure, and allow safe drainage flow.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 901.2 for vent purpose.

questions.question: Can testing be witnessed by someone other than the code official?

choices.text: No, only code official can witness

explanation.short: Others may witness tests with code official approval.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.2, the code official may accept tests witnessed by approved third parties or may require presence at certain tests based on jurisdiction requirements.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.2 for test witnessing.

questions.question: What is required if a test fails?

explanation.short: Failed tests require repairs and retesting.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.4, if any test shows defects, defective work shall be corrected and the system retested until it passes the required test.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.4 for test failures.

questions.question: What is the required identification for underground piping?

choices.text: Marking tape or tracer wire above non-metallic pipe

explanation.short: Underground non-metallic pipe requires tape or tracer wire.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 306.5 and local amendments, underground non-metallic piping shall have detectable marking tape or tracer wire for locating purposes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 306.5 and local requirements.

questions.question: What is required when notching or boring floor joists for piping?

choices.text: Limited to code-specified locations and sizes

explanation.short: Notching and boring limited by building code.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 307.1 and IRC, notches and holes in joists are limited in location (middle third) and size to maintain structural integrity.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 307.1 and building code.

questions.question: What protection is required when piping is within 1-1/2 inches of stud face?

explanation.short: Steel nail plate required when pipe within 1-1/2" of face.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 307.2, where piping is installed in studs, joists, or rafters within 1-1/2 inches of the edge, a steel protection plate minimum 1/16 inch thick is required.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 307.2 for nail plate requirement.

questions.question: What happens if work is concealed before inspection?

explanation.short: Code official may require uncovering concealed work.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.4, if work is concealed before required inspection, the code official may require that work be exposed for inspection at the permit holder's expense.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.4 for concealed work.

questions.question: How long is a plumbing permit typically valid?

explanation.short: Permits typically valid 180 days to 1 year.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 105.5, permits expire if work is not commenced within 180 days or if work is suspended/abandoned for 180 days. Extensions may be available.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 105.5 for permit validity.

questions.question: What is a stop-work order?

choices.text: Official order to cease all work due to violations

explanation.short: Stop-work order halts work due to code violations.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 108.4, when work is being done in violation of code, the code official may issue a stop-work order requiring immediate cessation of work until violations are corrected.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 108.4 for stop-work orders.

questions.question: Can a property owner appeal a code official's decision?

choices.text: Yes, to a board of appeals

explanation.short: Decisions may be appealed to board of appeals.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 109.1, any person aggrieved by a code official's decision may appeal to the board of appeals established to hear and decide matters under the code.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 109 for appeals process.

questions.question: What connections are prohibited to the sanitary drainage system?

explanation.short: Storm water and groundwater prohibited from sanitary sewer.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 302.1, storm water, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, and similar shall not be discharged into the sanitary drainage system.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 302.1 for prohibited connections.

questions.question: What accessibility requirement applies to plumbing fixtures?

choices.text: Compliance with ICC A117.1 for accessible fixtures

explanation.short: Accessible fixtures must comply with ICC A117.1.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 404.1, plumbing fixtures required to be accessible shall comply with ICC A117.1, Accessible and Usable Buildings and Facilities.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 404.1 for accessibility.

questions.question: What is required when plumbing interferes with structural members?

choices.text: Approval from architect/engineer or within code limits

explanation.short: Structural modifications require engineer approval or code limits.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 307.1, cutting, notching, or boring of structural members shall be within building code limits or approved by an architect or engineer.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 307.1 for structural requirements.

questions.question: What is workmanship standard for plumbing installations?

explanation.short: Plumbing shall be installed in neat and workmanlike manner.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 301.1, plumbing shall be installed in a neat and workmanlike manner. Pipe runs should be straight with proper support and alignment.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 301.1 for workmanship.

questions.question: What is required for connection to public sewer?

choices.text: Per local requirements and proper connection fitting

explanation.short: Sewer connection per local requirements and proper methods.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 701.2, connection to public sewer shall be per local requirements, typically requiring a watertight connection and possibly separate permit from sewer authority.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 701.2 and local sewer requirements.

questions.question: What is a shower pan test?

choices.text: Flood test to threshold height for 15 minutes

explanation.short: Shower pan flood tested to threshold for 15 minutes.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.9, site-built shower pans shall be tested by filling with water to the threshold height and allowing to stand for minimum 15 minutes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.9 for shower pan testing.

questions.question: What is a smoke test used for?

choices.text: Locating leaks in existing drainage systems

explanation.short: Smoke test locates leaks in drainage systems.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.6, smoke testing introduces smoke under pressure to locate leaks or defects in existing drainage and vent systems, especially useful in older buildings.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.6 for smoke testing.

questions.question: What is the maximum length of time a building sewer can remain uncovered?

explanation.short: Sewer remains uncovered until inspection is complete.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.1, building sewers shall remain accessible for inspection before covering. Once inspected and approved, they may be backfilled.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.1 for inspection timing.

questions.question: What gas is commonly used for medical gas system testing?

explanation.short: Nitrogen is used for medical gas system testing.
explanation.detailed: Per NFPA 99, medical gas systems are tested with oil-free dry nitrogen at specified pressures to verify system integrity before placing into service.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference NFPA 99 for medical gas testing.

questions.question: What is the code requirement for used or secondhand materials?

choices.text: Allowed if approved and in good condition

explanation.short: Used materials allowed if approved and in good condition.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 301.3, used materials may be reused if approved by the code official, free from defects, and conforming to requirements for new materials.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 301.3 for reused materials.

questions.question: What is a combined sewer system?

choices.text: Sanitary and storm water in same sewer

explanation.short: Combined sewer carries both sanitary and storm water.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1101.2, a combined sewer is a sewer receiving both sewage (sanitary) and stormwater runoff. Many older cities have combined systems.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1101.2 for combined sewer.

questions.question: What agency commonly lists/labels plumbing products?

explanation.short: NSF, IAPMO, UL, CSA are common plumbing testing agencies.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 301.2, products shall be listed by approved agencies such as NSF International, IAPMO, Underwriters Laboratories (UL), or CSA.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 301.2 for approved agencies.

questions.question: What trenching safety is required when installing underground piping?

explanation.short: OSHA excavation safety requirements apply.
explanation.detailed: Per OSHA 29 CFR 1926 Subpart P, trenches 5 feet or deeper require protection (sloping, shoring, or trench box) unless in stable rock. Even shallow trenches may need protection.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA 1926 Subpart P for excavation safety.

questions.question: At what trench depth is protection required per OSHA?

explanation.short: Trench protection required at 5 feet depth.
explanation.detailed: Per OSHA 1926.652, excavations 5 feet or deeper require protective systems unless the excavation is in stable rock. Shallower trenches may also require protection based on conditions.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA 1926.652 for excavation protection.

questions.question: What personal protective equipment is commonly required for plumbing work?

explanation.short: Safety glasses, gloves, and appropriate footwear required.
explanation.detailed: Per OSHA standards, PPE for plumbing typically includes safety glasses for eye protection, work gloves, and appropriate footwear. Specific tasks may require additional PPE.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA PPE requirements.

questions.question: What precaution is required when soldering copper pipe?

explanation.short: Ventilation and fire protection required when soldering.
explanation.detailed: When soldering, ensure adequate ventilation to prevent fume inhalation, have fire extinguisher nearby, protect combustibles, and use heat shields near flammable materials.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA hot work requirements and safe practices.

questions.question: What is required before entering a confined space like a septic tank?

choices.text: Atmospheric testing and permit-required entry procedures

explanation.short: Atmospheric testing and permit-required procedures needed.
explanation.detailed: Per OSHA 1910.146, confined spaces like septic tanks require atmospheric testing for oxygen deficiency and hazardous gases, plus permit-required entry procedures including attendant.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA 1910.146 for confined space entry.

questions.question: What is the code requirement for fixture accessibility for maintenance?

choices.text: Reasonable access for repair and replacement

explanation.short: Fixtures must have reasonable access for maintenance.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 405.2, plumbing fixtures shall be installed to provide reasonable access for service, repair, and replacement without requiring building demolition.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 405.2 for fixture access.

questions.question: What safety device is required on a sewage ejector basin?

explanation.short: Sewage ejector requires gas-tight, bolted cover.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 712.3.2, sewage ejector basins shall have gas-tight covers held in place by bolts or other approved fasteners to prevent sewer gas escape.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 712.3.2 for ejector cover.

questions.question: What is the minimum trap seal depth?

explanation.short: Minimum trap seal is 2 inches.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1002.4, traps shall have a minimum liquid seal of 2 inches and a maximum of 4 inches to effectively block sewer gases.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1002.4 for trap seal depth.

questions.question: What is the maximum trap seal depth?

explanation.short: Maximum trap seal is 4 inches.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1002.4, the maximum trap seal depth is 4 inches. Deeper seals can cause self-siphonage problems.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1002.4 for maximum trap seal.

questions.question: Which type of trap is prohibited?

explanation.short: S-traps are prohibited due to siphonage.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1003.2, S-traps, bell traps, and crown-vented traps are prohibited because their design allows self-siphonage, destroying the trap seal.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1003.2 for prohibited traps.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a cleanout?

explanation.short: Cleanouts provide access for clearing blockages.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 708.1, cleanouts provide access to the drainage system for clearing stoppages using snakes, augers, or water jetting equipment.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 708.1 for cleanout purpose.

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing between cleanouts on horizontal drains?

explanation.short: Cleanouts required every 100 feet maximum.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 708.3.4, horizontal drains shall have cleanouts at intervals not exceeding 100 feet for 4-inch and smaller pipes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 708.3.4 for cleanout spacing.

questions.question: Where must a cleanout be installed in the building drain?

choices.text: At base of each stack and at changes of direction

explanation.short: Cleanouts at stack base and changes in direction.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 708.3, cleanouts are required at the base of each waste/soil stack and at each aggregate change in direction exceeding 135 degrees.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 708.3 for cleanout locations.

questions.question: What is the minimum slope for a 4-inch or larger horizontal drain?

explanation.short: 4-inch and larger drains minimum 1/8 inch per foot slope.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 704.1, horizontal drainage piping 4 inches and larger shall have a minimum slope of 1/8 inch per foot (1% grade).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 704.1 for drain slope.

questions.question: What is the minimum slope for horizontal drains smaller than 4 inches?

explanation.short: Drains smaller than 4-inch need 1/4 inch per foot slope.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 704.1, horizontal drainage piping smaller than 4 inches shall have a minimum slope of 1/4 inch per foot (2% grade).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 704.1 for small drain slope.

questions.question: What is an indirect waste?

choices.text: Waste discharged through air gap to drainage

explanation.short: Indirect waste discharges through air gap to drainage.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 802.1, indirect waste is waste discharged from equipment through an air gap or air break into a floor sink, floor drain, or other receptor connected to drainage.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 802.1 for indirect waste definition.

questions.question: What type of trap is acceptable as an integral part of a fixture?

choices.text: Integral trap in water closet or urinal

explanation.short: Integral traps in toilets and urinals are acceptable.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1003.1, water closets and urinals have integral traps that are acceptable because they are designed as part of the fixture with proper seal protection.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1003.1 for integral traps.

questions.question: What is the minimum pipe size for a building sewer?

explanation.short: Minimum building sewer size is 4 inches.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 703.2, the building sewer pipe shall be minimum 4 inches in diameter to handle the total drainage load from the building.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 703.2 for building sewer size.

questions.question: What is the minimum cover for a building sewer?

explanation.short: Building sewer minimum 12-inch cover.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 306.3, building sewers shall have minimum 12 inches of cover unless protected from physical damage or in areas with vehicular traffic.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 306.3 for sewer cover depth.

questions.question: What is the building drain?

choices.text: Lowest horizontal piping inside building to sewer

explanation.short: Building drain is lowest horizontal piping inside to sewer.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, the building drain is the lowest horizontal piping inside the building that receives discharge from waste and soil stacks and conveys it to the building sewer.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for building drain definition.

questions.question: What is the building sewer?

choices.text: Piping from building to public sewer

explanation.short: Building sewer connects building drain to public sewer.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, the building sewer is the horizontal piping from the building drain (at 2-3 feet outside building) to the public sewer or private disposal.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for building sewer definition.

questions.question: What bedding material is required under plastic sewer pipe?

choices.text: Gravel or sand free of sharp objects

explanation.short: Plastic pipe needs gravel/sand bedding free of sharp objects.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 306.2, plastic pipe underground shall be uniformly supported on bedding material free of rocks, debris, and sharp objects that could damage the pipe.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 306.2 for pipe bedding.

questions.question: What equipment typically requires indirect waste connection?

explanation.short: Commercial refrigerators and HVAC condensate need indirect waste.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 802.1, food-handling equipment, refrigerators, ice makers, and HVAC condensate drains require indirect waste to prevent contamination of food or air.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 802.1 for indirect waste requirements.

questions.question: What causes trap seal loss from evaporation?

choices.text: Infrequent use allowing water to evaporate

explanation.short: Infrequent use allows trap water to evaporate.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1002.4, traps can lose their seal through evaporation when fixtures are not used regularly. Trap primers help maintain seal in rarely-used fixtures.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1002.4 for trap seal maintenance.

questions.question: What causes siphonage of a trap seal?

explanation.short: Negative pressure from poor venting causes siphonage.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 901.2, siphonage occurs when negative pressure (vacuum) in drainage pulls water from the trap. Proper venting prevents this by equalizing pressure.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 901.2 for siphonage prevention.

questions.question: What is a peppermint test?

choices.text: Odor test to detect leaks in drainage system

explanation.short: Peppermint test detects leaks by odor.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.8, peppermint (oil of peppermint) test introduces a strong odor into the drainage system. If the odor is detected inside, there's a leak in the system.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.8 for peppermint testing.

questions.question: What documents must be kept at job site during construction?

explanation.short: Approved permit and plans required at job site.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 106.3.1, the approved permit and construction documents shall be available at the job site for inspection during working hours.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 106.3.1 for site documents.

questions.question: What is a trap primer?

choices.text: Device that adds water to maintain trap seal

explanation.short: Trap primer adds water to maintain trap seal.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1002.4, a trap primer is a device that automatically supplies water to traps to maintain the seal, typically used on floor drains that receive infrequent use.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1002.4 for trap primers.

questions.question: What is a soil stack?

explanation.short: Soil stack is vertical pipe receiving water closet waste.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, a soil stack is a vertical drainage pipe that receives discharge from one or more water closets (toilets), with or without other fixtures.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for soil stack definition.

questions.question: What is a waste stack?

choices.text: Vertical pipe receiving fixtures other than toilets

explanation.short: Waste stack receives fixtures other than water closets.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, a waste stack is a vertical drainage pipe that receives discharge from fixtures other than water closets (sinks, lavatories, etc.).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for waste stack definition.

questions.question: What is a stack vent?

choices.text: Extension of soil/waste stack above highest fixture

explanation.short: Stack vent is extension of stack above highest fixture.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, a stack vent is the extension of a soil or waste stack above the highest horizontal drain connected to the stack, terminating through the roof.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for stack vent definition.

questions.question: How high must a vent terminate above the roof?

explanation.short: Vent must extend 6 inches minimum above roof.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 903.1, vent pipes shall extend through the roof and terminate at least 6 inches above the roof surface. In cold climates, 12 inches or more may be required.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 903.1 for vent termination height.

questions.question: What is the minimum distance from a vent termination to an operable window?

explanation.short: Vents must be 10 feet minimum from operable windows.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 903.5, vent terminations shall be at least 10 feet from operable windows, doors, or air intakes, or 3 feet above if within 10 feet horizontally.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 903.5 for vent location restrictions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a grease interceptor?

choices.text: Separate fats, oils, and grease from wastewater

explanation.short: Grease interceptor separates FOG from wastewater.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1003.3, grease interceptors separate and retain fats, oils, and grease (FOG) from wastewater before it enters the drainage system, preventing sewer blockages.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1003.3 for grease interceptor purpose.

questions.question: Where are grease interceptors required?

explanation.short: Required at commercial kitchens with grease-laden waste.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 1003.3.1, grease interceptors are required for commercial food establishments where grease-laden waste is discharged into the drainage system.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 1003.3.1 for grease interceptor requirements.

questions.question: What fitting is prohibited on horizontal drains?

explanation.short: Short-pattern (quarter bend) 90 prohibited on horizontal.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 706.3, short-pattern 90-degree fittings (quarter bends) are prohibited on horizontal drainage because they cause turbulent flow. Long-sweep or two 45s are required.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 706.3 for prohibited fittings.

questions.question: What fitting is used for horizontal to vertical drainage transition?

explanation.short: Wye with 1/8 bend or combination fitting for horizontal entry.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 706.3, horizontal drains connecting to vertical stacks require wye fittings with 1/8 bend or combination wye-eighth-bend fittings to maintain proper flow.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 706.3 for proper drain fittings.

questions.question: Can a sanitary tee be used on its back (horizontal inlet)?

explanation.short: Sanitary tee inlet must be vertical, not horizontal.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 706.3, sanitary tees can only receive flow from vertical (dropping) direction. They cannot be installed with horizontal (side) inlets in drainage; use wye instead.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 706.3 for sanitary tee orientation.

questions.question: What material is commonly used for DWV piping in residential?

explanation.short: PVC and ABS are common residential DWV materials.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 702.1, approved DWV materials include PVC, ABS, copper (DWV), cast iron, and others. PVC and ABS are most common in residential construction.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 702.1 for approved DWV materials.

questions.question: Can ABS and PVC be mixed in the same DWV system?

choices.text: Only with transition fittings or approved cement

explanation.short: ABS to PVC requires transition fittings or special cement.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.15, connections between ABS and PVC require approved transition fittings, mechanical couplings, or approved transition solvent cement per manufacturer instructions.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.15 for ABS/PVC transition.

questions.question: What is the minimum vent size for a 3-inch water closet drain?

explanation.short: Vent size determined by IPC Table 906.2.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 906.2, vent size for a 3-inch water closet drain is typically 2 inches minimum, but actual size depends on developed length and fixture units.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 906.2 for vent sizing.

questions.question: What is the penalty for performing plumbing without a permit?

choices.text: Fines and/or requirement to obtain permit

explanation.short: Work without permit may result in fines and permit requirement.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 108.4, violations of the code may result in fines, stop-work orders, and requirement to obtain proper permits. Repeated violations may result in license action.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 108.4 for violation penalties.

questions.question: What is the minimum horizontal offset for a building sewer under a building?

explanation.short: Building sewer 2 feet minimum from footings/foundations.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 306.4, building drain/sewer piping under buildings shall be at least 2 feet from bearing footings or foundations unless protected.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 306.4 for sewer location.

questions.question: Can a vent pipe be reduced in size as it goes up?

explanation.short: Vent size cannot be reduced below minimum required.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 903.3, vent piping shall not be reduced in size from the required minimum. The vent size is based on developed length and fixture load.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 903.3 for vent size requirements.

questions.question: What is an Air Admittance Valve (AAV)?

choices.text: One-way vent valve that opens on negative pressure

explanation.short: AAV is one-way valve allowing air in on negative pressure.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 918.1, an Air Admittance Valve is a one-way vent device that opens to admit air when negative pressure develops in the drainage system, preventing trap siphonage.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 918.1 for AAV definition.

questions.question: Where can an AAV be installed?

choices.text: Above flood level rim, in ventilated space, accessible

explanation.short: AAV installed above flood level, in ventilated accessible space.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 918.5, AAVs shall be installed above the flood level rim, in spaces with ventilation, and accessible for service. They cannot replace the main vent through roof.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 918.5 for AAV installation.

questions.question: Can AAVs replace all vents in a building?

choices.text: No, at least one vent must extend through roof

explanation.short: At least one vent must extend through roof.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 918.7, each building's drainage system requires at least one vent extending through the roof. AAVs can supplement but not replace all roof vents.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 918.7 for AAV limitations.

questions.question: What is a private sewage disposal system?

choices.text: On-site system like septic tank for buildings without public sewer

explanation.short: Private disposal serves buildings without public sewer access.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 11 (referenced to IPSDC), private sewage disposal systems include septic tanks and drainfields for properties not served by public sewer.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 11 for private disposal.

questions.question: What is the flood level rim?

choices.text: Top edge of fixture where water would overflow

explanation.short: Flood level rim is top edge where water overflows.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, the flood level rim is the edge of a fixture or receptor over which water would overflow - the maximum level water can reach before spilling.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 for flood level rim definition.

questions.question: What is the hazard of hydrogen sulfide gas in sewers?

choices.text: Toxic, potentially fatal at high concentrations

explanation.short: Hydrogen sulfide is toxic and potentially fatal.
explanation.detailed: Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) in sewers is toxic - it can cause unconsciousness and death at high concentrations. It also dulls sense of smell, making it more dangerous.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference OSHA hazard data for hydrogen sulfide.

questions.question: What is the primary hazard of methane in sewers?

explanation.short: Methane is flammable and explosive in confined spaces.
explanation.detailed: Methane accumulates in sewers and confined spaces. It's highly flammable and can cause explosions when mixed with air in concentrations between 5-15% (LEL to UEL).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference confined space hazard information.

questions.question: What joining method is used for cast iron no-hub pipe?

choices.text: No-hub coupling with stainless steel band

explanation.short: No-hub cast iron uses stainless steel band couplings.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.5, hubless cast iron pipe is joined with no-hub couplings consisting of a neoprene gasket and stainless steel band clamps.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.5 for no-hub connections.

questions.question: What is the purpose of solvent cement for plastic pipe?

choices.text: Chemical fusion of pipe and fitting

explanation.short: Solvent cement chemically fuses pipe and fitting.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.14, solvent cement for PVC and ABS dissolves the surfaces, allowing them to chemically fuse together into a permanent joint.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.14 for solvent cement joining.

questions.question: What primer is required before solvent cementing PVC pipe?

explanation.short: Purple primer required for PVC DWV joints.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.14.1, PVC pipe joints require primer conforming to ASTM F656. Purple tint is typically required to provide visible evidence of proper priming.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.14.1 for PVC primer.

questions.question: Is primer required for ABS pipe?

choices.text: No, ABS solvent cement bonds without primer

explanation.short: ABS does not require primer before cementing.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.14.2, ABS pipe connections use ABS solvent cement without primer. The cement itself provides adequate surface preparation for ABS material.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.14.2 for ABS joining.

questions.question: What takes precedence when there's a conflict between code sections?

explanation.short: More restrictive requirement takes precedence.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 102.1, when different sections of the code specify different requirements for the same installation, the most restrictive requirement governs.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 102.1 for code conflicts.

questions.question: Does existing plumbing need to be upgraded to current code?

choices.text: Only when alterations are made or hazards exist

explanation.short: Existing legal installations may remain unless altered or hazardous.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 102.2, existing plumbing installations lawful at time of installation may remain unless the code official determines a hazard or until alterations are made.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 102.2 for existing installations.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a backwater valve?

explanation.short: Backwater valve prevents sewer backup into building.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 715.1, a backwater valve is a check valve installed on the building drain to prevent sewage from backing up into the building during sewer surcharge.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 715.1 for backwater valves.

questions.question: Where is a backwater valve typically required?

choices.text: Where fixtures are below street/sewer level

explanation.short: Required where fixtures are below sewer/street level.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 715.1, backwater valves are required when fixtures are installed below the level of the public sewer or where backup is possible.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 715.1 for backwater valve requirements.

questions.question: What is a rough-in inspection?

choices.text: Inspection of piping before walls are closed

explanation.short: Rough-in inspection before walls/ceilings are closed.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.1, rough-in inspection examines DWV and water piping before walls, ceilings, or other concealment occurs, allowing visual inspection and testing.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.1 for inspection stages.

questions.question: What is a final plumbing inspection?

explanation.short: Final inspection with all fixtures installed and functional.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 107.1, final inspection verifies complete plumbing system including fixtures, water heater, and all connections operating properly.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 107.1 for final inspection.

questions.question: What minimum air test duration is required for DWV?

explanation.short: DWV air test minimum 15 minutes at 5 psi.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.2, DWV air test shall maintain 5 psi for a minimum of 15 minutes without pressure drop indicating leaks.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.2 for air test duration.

questions.question: What determines pipe support spacing?

choices.text: IPC Table 308.5 by material and size

explanation.short: Support spacing per IPC Table 308.5.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 308.5, pipe support intervals are specified in Table 308.5 based on pipe material, size, and whether horizontal or vertical.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 308.5 for support spacing.

questions.question: What is the maximum horizontal support spacing for 4-inch PVC DWV?

explanation.short: 4-inch PVC DWV horizontal support every 4 feet.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 308.5, PVC DWV pipe requires horizontal support at 4-foot intervals for all sizes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 308.5 for PVC support spacing.

questions.question: What is the maximum horizontal support spacing for cast iron pipe?

explanation.short: Cast iron horizontal support every 5 feet (at each joint).
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 308.5, cast iron pipe requires horizontal support at intervals of 5 feet, typically at each joint for hub-and-spigot pipe.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 308.5 for cast iron support.

questions.question: What is required when backfilling over plastic pipe?

choices.text: Initial cover with fine material, then careful compaction

explanation.short: Initial fine material cover, then careful compaction.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 306.2, plastic pipe shall be protected during backfill with initial cover of fine material free of rocks before compaction to prevent damage.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 306.2 for backfill requirements.

questions.question: What is a mechanical joint?

choices.text: Connection using compression or clamping devices

explanation.short: Mechanical joints use compression or clamping.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 705.6, mechanical joints include compression fittings, no-hub couplings, push-fit connections, and other methods using physical clamping rather than fusion.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 705.6 for mechanical joints.

questions.question: What is a DFU (Drainage Fixture Unit)?

choices.text: Unit of probable discharge load from fixture

explanation.short: DFU measures probable discharge load from fixtures.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Chapter 2, a drainage fixture unit (DFU) is a unit value assigned to fixtures to express probable discharge load for drain sizing purposes.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Chapter 2 and Table 709.1 for DFU.

questions.question: What is the DFU value for a residential water closet?

explanation.short: Residential water closet = 4 DFU.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 709.1, a water closet (private, tank type) has a drainage fixture unit value of 4 DFU for sizing drain piping.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 709.1 for fixture DFU values.

questions.question: What is the DFU value for a lavatory?

explanation.short: Lavatory = 1 DFU.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 709.1, a lavatory (private) has a drainage fixture unit value of 1 DFU.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 709.1 for lavatory DFU.

questions.question: What is the DFU value for a bathtub with shower?

explanation.short: Bathtub with shower = 2 DFU.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Table 709.1, a bathtub with or without shower (private) has a drainage fixture unit value of 2 DFU.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Table 709.1 for bathtub DFU.

questions.question: What materials are approved for underground building sewer?

choices.text: PVC, ABS, cast iron, and other approved materials

explanation.short: Multiple approved materials for underground sewer.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 702.2, approved materials for underground building sewer include PVC, ABS, extra-heavy cast iron, concrete, and vitrified clay (where approved).
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 702.2 for sewer materials.

questions.question: What is required when cutting cast iron pipe?

choices.text: Snap cutter or abrasive saw with eye and ear protection

explanation.short: Use snap cutter or abrasive saw with PPE.
explanation.detailed: Cast iron cutting with snap cutters or abrasive saws requires eye protection (flying chips) and hearing protection (noise). A square cut is essential for proper joining.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference safe cutting practices for cast iron.

questions.question: A DWV test fails due to pressure drop. What is the first step?

explanation.short: First locate the leak using soap solution or other method.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 312.4, when a test fails, locate the leak using soap solution (for air test) or visual inspection (water test), repair, and retest until passing.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 312.4 for test failure procedure.

questions.question: What markings must appear on approved plumbing materials?

choices.text: Manufacturer, standard, and agency listing mark

explanation.short: Materials must show manufacturer, standard, and listing mark.
explanation.detailed: Per IPC Section 301.2, listed plumbing materials shall bear manufacturer identification, applicable standard reference, and listing agency mark.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC Section 301.2 for material marking.

questions.question: What document provides the model plumbing code adopted by many states?

explanation.short: IPC is the model code adopted by many states.
explanation.detailed: The International Plumbing Code (IPC), published by ICC, is the model plumbing code adopted by many states and local jurisdictions, sometimes with amendments.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference IPC adoption maps and state regulations.

questions.question: What alternative model plumbing code is used primarily in western states?

explanation.short: UPC is the model code used primarily in western states.
explanation.detailed: The Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC), published by IAPMO, is the alternative model code used primarily in California and other western states.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference plumbing code adoption by state.
